ags:resource.dc:title: Thunderstorm prediction through stability indices for Lahore, Peshawar and Karachi, Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Sadiq, N. (Karachi Univ. (Pakistan). Inst. of Space and Planetary Astrophysics)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 1 table, 7 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: nsadiq@uok.edu.pk
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: An attempt is made here to develop a methodology to comprehend the forecast of thunderstorms through two important stability indices viz. George K Index and Total Totals Index for Lahore Peshawar and Karachi stations. The study is based on the analysis of 374 events during ten years (1996-2005). The findings infer mean values of K-Index as 35 and 25 for summer and winter, respectively, while threshold value of TT-Index comes out as 40 for the both seasons. The case study of July 30, 2006 is also incorporated for Karachi. The hypothesis and the most fitting ranges of different stability indices suggested in this research have yet to be testified and confirmed before the same can be used as one of the forecasting tools. This study will probably help the operational to make use of various stability indices and is expected to improve the weather forecast as this will be in addition to the convectional forecasting techniques now being used in Pakistan.

ags:resource.dc:title: Occurrence of thunderstorm and rainfall over Punjab, Pakistan (1961-2010)

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Sadiq, N. (Karachi Univ. (Pakistan). Inst. of Space and Planetary Astrophysics)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 9 ills., 2 tables, 9 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: nsadiq@uok.edu.pk
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Occurrence of Thunderstorms (TS) and Rainfalls (RF) are contemplated via monthly, station wise seasonal and overall seasonal percentage analysis for all over the Punjab. Fifty years (1961-2010) data of the mentioned parameters for thirteen meteorological stations, uniformly distributed over the province, were utilized in this study. Monthly study has revealed the highest activity of TS and RF in the two months of monsoon (July and August) while rainfall occurrence acquired second highest frequency in the end of winter (March). Overall seasonal analysis shows markedly high activity of TS and RF in premonsoon and monsoon season while in winter RF frequency is almost twofold than TF. Further, rainfall yield in post-monsoon and winter explore that all stations acquire much more RF accompanied with little TS activity. The situation is altogether different for premonsoon and monsoon, while for post-monsoon it is composite. The results of this paper will help to provide updated cogitative assistance not only to the people concerned with the science, art or business of cultivating the soil but also to the community concerned with weather, aviation and planning.

ags:resource.dc:title: Relative degree of susceptibility and resistance of different Brassica campestris L. genotypes against aphid Myzus persicae - A field investigation

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Sarwar, M. (Nuclear Inst. of Agriculture, Tandojam (Pakistan))

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 1 table, 18 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: drsarwar64@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Field evaluation of twenty three Brassica campestris L. genotypes was conducted for aphid (Homoptera: Aphididae) resistance during 2008 crop season. The parameters used to assess tolerance of germplasm lines included pest population during growth season and grain yield at crop maturity. Aphids showed obvious preferences for all of the germplasm investigated; however, the evaluation for resistance to pest identified several genotypes with variable potential for tolerance and sensitivity. Estimated grain yield also varied significantly due to variable pest intensity noted, and seemed to be more appropriately dependent on the pest population conditions at the experimental site. Among the germplasm, the estimation obtained regarding both the parameters sorted out MM-II/02-3 and MM-1285 genotypes as most tolerant due to less pest infestation and damage. Peak infestations by aphid caused severe crop fatalities on S-9-S-97-0.75+75/55 and S-9-1006/95 genotypes, affecting the seed weight ad resulting an immense reduction in grain produced. The degrees of aphids' population and infestation on different Brassica genotypes appeared to be governed by means of varietals characteristics of diverse germplasms. The result of resistance test conducted under field environment is an effective and consistent approach in the practical selection of crop lines resistant or partially resistant to pests for use in future breeding programs.

ags:resource.dc:title: Thunderstorm and rainfall frequencies over Sindh, Pakistan for the period 1961-2010

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Sadiq, N. (Karachi Univ. (Pakistan). Inst. of Space and Planetary Astrophysics)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 11 ills., 2 tables, 12 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: nsadiq@uok.edu.pk
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The study is aimed to analyze the fifty years 91961-2010) data of Thunderstorm (TS) and Rainfall (RF) frequencies for the Sindh province via nine meteorological stations that are almost unevenly distributed over the region. Monthly, overall seasonal and station wise seasonal percentages are calculated and analyzed. In addition, percentage frequency comparison of TS and RF are also incorporated. Both the activities are observed with greatest frequency (59%) in monsoon while annual diversity of TS is found greater than RF. During monsoon period, Badin is the most while Jacobabad and Larkana are the least affected reported stations by frequent storms along with rainfall, respectively.

ags:resource.dc:title: Removal of cadmium, copper, lead and zinc from simulated industrial effluents using silica powder

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Javed, T. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Isotope Application Div.)
Awan, F.A. (International Islamic Univ., Islamabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Environmental Sciences)
Arshad, M. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Isotope Application Div.)
Mashiatullah, A.
Iftikhar, F.J.
Khan, S.N.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 4 ills., 1 table, 24 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: mashiatullah@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Rapid industrial development have led to the recognition and increasing understanding of interrelationship between pollution, public health and environment. Industrial development results in the generation of industrial effluents, and it untreated results in water, sediment and soil pollution. In Pakistan most of the industrial effluents are discharged into surrounding ecosystems without any treatment. Industrial wastes and emission contain toxic and hazardous substances, most of which are detrimental to human health. Extensive efforts are being made around the world for the removal of heavy metal from industrial effluents. A laboratory scale study was designed for removal of Cd, Cu, Pb and Zn from simulated solutions at various weight of silica (0.5gm, 1 g, 2 gm, 3gm and 4 gm), Voltammeter was used to quantify the metals. Maximum removal of all metals was achieved with 4 gm of silica. Absorption of lead onto silica was higher than other metals.

ags:resource.dc:title: Phytoplanktons and zooplanktons diversity in Karachi coastal seawater under high and low tide during winter monsoon

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Yaqoob, N. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Isotope Application Div.)
Mashiatullah, A. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Isotope Application Div.)
Chughtai, F. (Karachi Univ. (Pakistan). Centre of Excellence in Marine Biology)
Sehr, N.
Javed, T.
Ghaffar, A.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 5 ills., 3 tables, 18 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: mashiatullah@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: This paper represents the population density of phytoplanktons and zooplanktons recorded during the marine environmental studies at Karachi coast in the month of February 2011. Samples were collected by towing net, preserved and quantification and identification was carried out under light microscope. Twenty-three phytoplanktons species and nine zooplankton groups were recorded in the seawater from the sampling area of 10 square kilometers. Coscinodiscus and Copepods were dominant in the population of phytoplankton and zooplankton, respectively. Phytoplankton population density increased while zooplankton abundance decreased offshore from the coastline in the open sea.

ags:resource.dc:title: Trace element analysis of some medicinal herbs by proton induced x-ray emission (PIXE)

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Ahmad, N. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Centre for Advanced Studies in Physics)
Naeem, A. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Centre for Advanced Studies in Physics)
Saadat, S. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Centre for Advanced Studies in Physics)
Shahnawaz, M.
Rafique, M.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 1 ill., 3 tables, 14 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: dmisarahmadsi@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Proton induced X-ray Emission (PIXE) has been used to investigate the concentration of nineteen trace elements in eleven medicinal herbs commonly used for the treatment of different diseases in Pakistan. Mg, Si, K, Ca and Fe were detected in all the medicinal herbs studied. Germanium has been detected only in violet flower. Indian Lilac, field marigold and violet flower have the highest number of trace elements with maximum concentration. No toxic elements such as Pb, Hg etc. were detected in these medicinal herbs. The accuracy of our results was validated by analyzing standard reference material Citrus Leaf (NIST- SRM -1572). Results indicate that medicinal herbs are a rich source of trace elements which may be useful for the cure of certain ailments.

ags:resource.dc:title: Pollution level assessment of road dust from Islamabad expressway

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Faiz, Y. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Chemistry Div., Directorate of Science)
Siddique, N. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Chemistry Div., Directorate of Science)
Tufail, M. (Pakistan Inst. of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Islamabad (Pakistan))

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 4 tables, 32 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: nailasiddique@yahoo.ca
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Thirteen road dust and four soil samples were analyzed using Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis (INAA) and Flame Atomic Absorption Spectroscopy (FAAS) to determine the elemental composition of road dust collected from Islamabad Expressway. Pollution parameters and indicators such as Enrichment Factors (EFs), Pollution Load Index (PLI), Geoaccumulation Index (Igeo), Pollution Index (PI) and Integrated Pollution Index (IPI) were calculated and showed that the area around Islamabad Expressway is low to moderately polluted especially by elements such as Mg and Sb. The IPI of the elements was found to vary in the order; Mg greater than Sb greater than Cu greater than Sr almost equal to Pb greater than Ga greater than Na greater than Sn almost equal to Zn greater than Yb greater than Se greater than Hf. The 5 samples collected around the busy intersections of Faizabad and Zero Point have higher amounts of most of the elements determined. Moreover the pollution indices for these samples indicate that these sites are more contaminated than the remaining 8 sampling sites.

ags:resource.dc:title: Phytoremediation using Eichhornia crassipes aquatic plant

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Majid, A. (Pakistan Inst. of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Islamabad (Pakistan))
Siddique, N. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Chemistry Div., Directorate of Science)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 4 ills., 2 tables, 27 ref., Summary (En)
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Phytoremediation is a cost effective approach for the treatment of polluted soil and contaminated water. The effectiveness of one aquatic plant Eichhornia crassipes was evaluated for its capability in removing copper from copper solution using atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS). The aquatic plant was placed in solutions containing 2 mg/L, 4 mg/L and 6 mg/L of copper, for a period of 18 days and the change in Cu concentration was measured. Results showed an increase of copper within the plants' root and shoot tissues and a decrease of copper concentration in the solution. It was found that roots tend to accumulate a higher amount of copper than shoots due to translocation process. The maximum growth of Eichhornia crassipes was in the 2 mg/L solution which shows that growth was affected by the presence of Cu in the water. The maximum removal of copper in the solutions containing Eichhornia crassipes was 87.5% from the 4 mg/L solution. Eichhornia crassipes accumulated upto 1265.0 mg/kg of Cu in its roots indicating that this aquatic plant species may be used as a hyper-accumulator for copper.

ags:resource.dc:title: Estimation of trace metal contents in locally-baked breads

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Khalid, N. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Chemistry Div., Directorate of Science)
Rehman, S. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Chemistry Div., Directorate of Science)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 1 ill., 5 tables, 21 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: sohailarahman@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: In order to establish base line levels, estimation of some essential trace metals (Cu, Fe, Mn & Zn) has been conducted in four brands of fifteen locally baked breads of Rawalpindi/Islamabad area employing Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometry (AAS). The reliability of the procedure employed was verify by analyzing Standard Reference Material, i.e., wheat flour (NBS-SRM-1567) for its Cu, Fe, Mn and Zn contents which were in good agreement with the certified values. The results revealed that brown breads contained higher amount of Fe 1771.3 mug g-1 and Zn 19.27 mug g-1 while levels of Cu 21.90 mug g-1 was found higher in the samples of plain bread. The determined metal concentrations in the bread samples were compared with the reported values for other countries. The effect of kneading/baking/slicing processes on the concentration levels of these metals was also studied. The daily intake of these metals through this source was calculated and compared with the recommended dietary allowance.

ags:resource.dc:title: Radiological health impact due to activity concentrations of natural radionuclides in the soils from two major areas in IJEBU-North Local Government, Ogun State, Nigeria

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Alausa, S.K. (Olabisi Onabanjo Univ., Ago-lwoye (Nigeria). Dept. of Physics)
Odusote, O.O. (Olabisi Onabanjo Univ., Ago-lwoye (Nigeria). Dept. of Physics)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 1 ill., 3 tables, 29 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: alausakunle@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The soil samples from two major areas in Ijebu-North Local Government of Ogun State was analyzed for the concentrations of 40K, 226Ra and 232Th using gamma ray spectrometry method. The measured activity concentrations of 40K varied from 245.2 Bq per kg to 538.1 Bq per kg with a mean value of 367.9 plus minus 74.1 Bq per kg 226Ra in the ranged from 10.4 Bq per kg to 30.2 Bq per kg with a mean value of 16.4 plus minus 4.6 Bq per kg and 232Th ranged from below detection limit (BDL) to 14.1 Bq per kg with a mean value of 3.3 plus minus 2.0 Bq per kg. The mean external gamma absorbed dose rate in air at 1m above the ground level was 26.4 plus minus 5.1 nGyth-1 which was just about one-half of 56.0 nGyh-1 recommended by UNSCEAR (2000). The mean annual outdoor effective dose rate was 32.3 plus minus 6.3 muSvy-1. The collective dose equivalent was 9.18 manSv while the collective health detriment of the population was 0.15y-1.

ags:resource.dc:title: Integration of renewable energy sources in smart grid: A review

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Zafar, S. (University of Engineering and Technology, Taxila (Pakistan). Electrical Engineering Dept.)
Nawaz, K. (University of Engineering and Technology, Taxila (Pakistan). Electrical Engineering Dept.)
Naqvi, S.A.R. (University of Engineering and Technology, Taxila (Pakistan). Electrical Engineering Dept.)
Malik, T.N.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 71 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: salmanuett@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The increasing complexity of the existing power grid due to rapid population growth, development in technology, infrastructure and computational tools are the factors that contribute to the need of deployment of smart grid for secure and efficient use of electrical energy. The modernization of electric grids toward a smart grid is being carried out to improve reliability, facilitate integration of renewable energies, and improve power consumption management. Due to continuous depletion of primary fuel resources and global concern about the environmental pollution, the development of smart grids based on renewable energy resources has gained huge strategic significance now a days to resolve the energy crisis. However the intermittent this paper briefly discuss the emerging renewable energy resources (RERs) and Energy storage systems (EES). Secondly this work comprehensively reviews the potential challenges in integration of these sources in smart grid along with the applied control strategies for their facilitation and some practical case studies.

ags:resource.dc:title: Monitoring and quantification of soil water content and fluxes in deep layers of wheat cultivated soils to improve water use efficiency

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Iqbal, N. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Isotope Application Div.)
Iqbal, T. (Pakistan Inst. of Nuclear Science and Technology, Islamabad (Pakistan). Isotope Application Div.)
Ishaque, W. (Nuclear Inst. for Agriculture and Biology, Faisalabad (Pakistan))
Rafiq, M.
Fazil, M.
Ghaffar, A.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 8 ills., 3 tables, 18 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: niqbal@pinstech.org.pk
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Calculation of irrigation scheduling (IS) and improvement irrigated water use efficiency (WUE) requires precise measurement of soil water content and fluxes in the soil layers. Deep irrigation fluxes in agricultural field of wheat crop at the Nuclear Institute of Agriculture & Biology (NIAB), Faisalabad, Pakistan were monitored and quantified using radio and stable isotope techniques. The time variant soil moisture content data were also used to determine the fluxes by water balance technique. The fluxes determined by isotope and water balance technique in accordance with crop water consumption and to reduce the water loss through deep percolation.

ags:resource.dc:title: Effect of L-tryptophan on plant weight and pod weight in chickpea under rainfed conditions

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Abbas, S.H. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Crop Sciences Inst.)
Sohail, M. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Crop Sciences Inst.)
Saleem, M. (Nuclear Inst. for Agriculture and Biology, Faisalabad (Pakistan))
Mahmood, T. (Pir Mehr Ali Shah Arid Agriculture Univ., Rawalpindi (Pakistan). Dept. of Environmental Sciences)
Aziz, I. (Pir Mehr Ali Shah Arid Agriculture Univ., Rawalpindi (Pakistan). Dept. of Environmental Sciences)
Qamar, M. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Crop Sciences Inst.)
Majeed, A. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Crop Sciences Inst.)
Arif, M. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Plant Genetic Resources Inst.)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 2 tables, 13 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: hakazmi79@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Exogenous application of plant growth regulators is an important element in modern day agricultural production technology. The precursor of auxin, L-Tryptophan (L-TRP), is the most important plant growth regulator and is physiologically very vital in modeling plant growth and development. To evaluate the effect of L-TRP on chickpea plant weight and pod weight, a field experiment was conducted during 2003, employing randomized complete block design under rain-fed conditions. The treatments were L-TRP @ 10-2M, L-TRP @ 10-3M, L-TRP @ 10-4M and a control. Analysis showed that L-TRP @ 10-3M had a significant effect on plant and pod weight, suggesting the additional effect of plant growth promoting factor provided by auxin production. The L-TRP improved the crop vegetative and reproductive growth that consequently increases pod weight.

ags:resource.dc:title: Estimation of best parents and superior cross combinations for yield and fiber quality related traits in upland cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L.)

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Shaukat, S. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Plant Breeding and Genetics)
Khan, T.M. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Plant Breeding and Genetics)
Shakeel, A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Plant Breeding and Genetics)
Ijaz, S. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Centre of Agricultural Biochemistry and Biotechnology)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 tables, 15 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: shadab_uaf@hotmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Combining ability was studied for identification of potential cultivars and hybrids in upland cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L.) in a 6x6 set of diallel crosses among six genotypes of cotton, i.e., VH-232, CRS-2007, SB-149, GR-156, FH-207, and MARVI carried out on fiber length, fiber fineness, fiber elongation, fiber strength, ginning out tern (GOT) and seed cotton yield. Analysis of variance revealed highly significant (p less than or equal to 0.01) differences among the genotypes for all traits. Combining ability studies showed that the mean squares, due to general combining ability (GCA), specific combining ability (SCA) and reciprocal effects were highly significant in F1 generation. Genetic components, due to GCA and SCA, revealed that traits, such as, fiber length, strength and fineness, showed high proportion of additive type of gene action in F1 generation because of greater GCA variances were greater than SCA variance. GR-156 was the best combiner for lint percentage and fiber length. FH-207 was the best combiner for fiber fineness. FH-207, MARVI and SB-149 were the best general combiners for fiber character and were suggested to be used in future breeding programme to improve fiber quality traits. CRS-2007 x GR-156, CRS-2007 x MARVI, SB-149 x MARVI and VH-232 x SB-149 had higher specific combining ability and reciprocal effects and they can be used for future breeding programme to improve fiber quality.

ags:resource.dc:title: Influence of foliar application of potassium on wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) under saline conditions

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Khan, A. (University of Sargodha (Pakistan). Dept. of Biological Sciences)
Aziz, M. (University of Sargodha (Pakistan). Dept. of Biological Sciences)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 tables, 24 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: ameeruaf@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: A potted experiment was conducted in the Department of Biological Sciences, University of Sargodha, to determine the effect of potassium (K) on wheat under saline and non-saline conditions. Foliar spray of K (0, 300, 600 mgL-1) was applied on wheat under different salinity levels (0, 150 mmol). Salinity levels were created according to the saturation percentage of the soil. Each pot was filled with 7kg well-mixed soil. This experiment was laid out in a randomised complete block design with two factors factorial arrangement and with three replications. Different growth and physiological attributes were collected from the conducted experiment. Application of K increased the shoot and root fresh and dry weight. Salinity also affected the chlorophyll contents but the application of K enhanced the chlorophyll contents under saline and non-saline conditions. Foliar application of K also minimized the toxicity of sodium. Similarly, grains yield was also decreased under saline conditions but the foliar application of K reduced the salinity stress and enhanced the grains yield. These results indicated that foliar-applied K ameliorated the effect of salinity on wheat plants.

ags:resource.dc:title: Hydraulic performance evaluation of pressure compensating (PC) emitters and micro-tubing for drip irrigation system

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Mangrio, A.G. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Alternate Energy and Water Resource Inst.)
Asif, M. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Alternate Energy and Water Resource Inst.)
Ahmed, E. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Agricultural Engineering)
Sabir, M.W.
Khan, T.
Jahangir, I.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 9 tables, 15 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: mangrioghafoor@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Drip irrigation system is necessary for those areas, where the water scarcity issues are present. The present study was conducted at the field station of Climate Change, Alternate Energy and Water Resources Institute (CAEWRI), National Agricultural Research Center (NARC), Islamabad, during 2013, regarding drip irrigation system. Drip irrigation system depends on uniform emitter application flow. All the emitters were tested and replicated thrice at pressure head (34 to 207Kpa) with an increment of 34 Kpa. The minimum and maximum discharges were 1.32 - 3.52, 3.36 - 5.42, and 43.22 - 100.99 Lph, with an average of 2.42, 4.63 and 73.66 Lph, for Bow Smith, RIS and Micro-tubing, respectively. It indicates that more than 90% of emission uniformity (EU) and uniformity coefficient (CU) for all Emitters, which shows excellent water application with least standard deviation, ranging 0.12 to 2.37, throughout the operating pressure heads in all emitters. An average coefficient of variation (CV) of all emitters were behaving less than 0.07, indicating an excellent class at all operating pressure heads between 34 to 207 Kpa. Moreover, the relationship of discharge and pressure of emitters indicates that discharge increased with the increase of pressure head. The Q-H curve plays key role in the selection of emitters.

ags:resource.dc:title: Evaluation of different seepage control measures for a proposed "golen gol" weir in Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Khan, B. (CECOS Univ. of I.T. and Emerging Sciences, Peshawar (Pakistan). Dept. of Civil Engineering)
Amin, M. (Neelum-Jehlum Hydroelectric Project, Muzaffarabad (Pakistan))
Badshah, N. (Government Coll. of Technology, Peshawar (Pakistan))

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 9 ills., 4 tables, 12 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: bmarwat@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The Golen Gol weir foundation is pervious and there is a worry of considerable seepage. To control seepage, a scaled model of the weir section and its foundation was developed in SEEP/W and analyzed for seepage quantity. The analysis was divided into several trials. In one trial, a continuous pervious foundation of weir without any seepage control measure was modeled and analyzed for seepage quantity. This was used as a base (reference) case for comparison. In other trails, different seepage control measures, such as, downstream filter, upstream blanket, cut-off (upstream, mid, downstream) and combination of upstream blanket and cut-off, were used. Different lengths of upstream blanket and depths of cut-off were tried. In each trial, twenty different material regions were defined and hydraulic conductivity function (K-ratio = Ky/Kx) was defined for each region. Also, a total head of 2052m, on the upstream side, was selected as one of the boundary condition for the study problem. The results of the analysis revealed that the upstream blanket of length 30m and combination of downstream and upstream blankets (each 10m deep) showed nearly equal reduction in seepage quantity. However, the exit gradient for blanket was found more on safe side and also its cost of construction was estimated less than the cost of the cut-offs.

ags:resource.dc:title: Ethno-botanical studies of economically important plants from mountainous region of Gilgit-Baltistan, Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Awan, M.R. (Hazara Univ., Mansehra (Pakistan). Dept. of Botany)
Jamal, Z. (Government Post Graduate Coll., Abbottabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Botany)
Khan, A. (Hazara Univ., Mansehra (Pakistan). Dept. of Botany)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 9 ills., 2 tables, 8 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: awan48us@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Ethno botanical studies of economically important plants from Gilgit-Baltistan were conducted during 2003-2006. Extensive field trips were conducted for collection of plants according to their flowering and fruiting period and ethno-botanical data obtained during field trips. This area has many ecological zones, lies between 3000ft to 29000ft above sea level. Due to difference in soil, climate, moisture contents, latitude, longitude, altitude and topography, great diversity of plants of economic importance were found in these areas. Locals belonging to different ethnic groups, like, Sayyed, Gujjar, Mughal, Sheen, Yaskuin, Wakhi, Tajik, Khowar, etc., are settled there. They have distinct life styles, beliefs, traditions, life style and culture. There is a great shortage medical treatment therefore locals use indigenous plants for treatment of various diseases at local level. Folklore treatment is considered the cheapest source of curing diseases at local level. Information regarding ethno-medicinal importance was obtained from local inhabitants of old age. These plants have been utilized over many generations by various ethnic groups. It was found that indigenous medicinal flora of the area is quite rich and is diverse, due to the difference in altitude, climate and other topographic conditions. It is expected that this paper will be beneficial for locals, students, researchers, farmers, foresters and general public alike.

ags:resource.dc:title: Energy crises and solutions

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Ali, I. (Pakistan Council of Scientific and Industrial Research, Karachi (Pakistan). Fuel Research Centre)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 10 tables, 14 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: pakassp@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Energy consumption is one of the parameters for measuring the prosperity of a country. Energy situation of Pakistan has been critical for the last few years as the reserves of natural resources of energy are depleting at a very fast rate, resulting in the current energy crises and load shedding, badly affecting industrial and agricultural growth. Based on the observations and experience, energy resources of the country have been discussed, emphasizing on the utilization of indigenous resources, particularly, coal and hydel resources for minimizing dependence on imported energy. Research and development work, carried out in the country on various fuels, has been discussed. Among them coal briquetting, coal carbonization (coking) of Sharigh coal, extraction of chemicals and desulphurization of Pakistani lignites have been discussed. Studies on alternate/renewable and non-conventional sources of energy have also been presented with special reference to bio-gas, solar and wind energies, etc.

ags:resource.dc:title: Comparing different approaches to assess environmental vulnerabilities

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Jalil, A. (Punjab Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Centre for Integrated Mountain Research)
Khan, K. (Punjab Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Centre for Integrated Mountain Research)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 26 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: jalil_ahmed21@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: In this review article, we have compared different approaches to assess vulnerability of environmental systems, and also identified and analyzed the major adaptations by the world to measure the environmental vulnerability and their points of convergence of what otherwise might be characterized in the given field of research. The large number of indices and frameworks has been developed to measure the environmental vulnerability. Similarly, there are some assessment methods to assess environmental vulnerability. In this regard, there are many publications that have been published specially in the previous decade, and many from them were considered in this article to find out the best method to deal with environmental vulnerability. We concluded that, by integrating all the components of environmental vulnerability into a common framework within a single context, a reasonable setting for measuring the level of environmental vulnerability could be assessed. Index of simple numeric values for individual component should be developed within each framework of that component. We argued that multiple approaches to measure the environmental vulnerability should be considered to analyze the best to adapt. We have pointed-out the major questions that could be raised in the minds of researchers for the development of risk free (Resilient) societies. We suggested developing the framework of such capability that could be modified by the nations to use it, at their local context.

ags:resource.dc:title: Comparative assessment of wheat landraces against polyethylene glycol simulated drought stress

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Jatoi, S.A. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Plant Genetic Resources Inst.)
Latif, M.M. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Plant Genetic Resources Inst.)
Arif, M. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Plant Genetic Resources Inst.)
Ahson, M.
Khan, A.
Siddiqui, S.U.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 2 tables, 13 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: sajatoi@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Current investigation reports a comparative assessment and relative performance of 10 wheat accessions including check variety Inqilab-91 against polyethylene glycol (PEG) simulated drought stress at seedling. Wheat genotypes were tested against 0, 19, 21, 23 and 25% solutions of PEG 6000. The young seedlings were observed for germination (%) and root length (cm). In general, a decrease in germination percentage was observed with the increase in PEG concentration. All the investigated wheat genotypes performed better than the check variety Inqilab-91. The wheat accession 18699 that had more than 30% surviving seedlings at the highest concentration of used PEG was rated as the tolerant genotype. On the other hand, 18671 and 18698 appeared to be less tolerant having less than 5% germination at 25% PEG. Similarly, the root length decreased with the increase in PEG concentrations. The mean root length of all the wheat accessions, which were studied, was comparatively less affected than the control (Inqilab-91). The wheat genotypes 18670 and 18671 were the better performers than the rest of genotypes investigated and belonged to rainfed area of the Pothowar region. A detailed investigation of these genotypes in the field conditions is suggested.

ags:resource.dc:title: Distribution of micronutrients in different soil series around Tandojam, Sindh, Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Dahar, G.J. (Sindh Agriculture Univ., Tandojam (Pakistan))
Baloch, P.A. (PARC Plant Introduction Centre, Karachi (Pakistan))
Abro, B.A. (PARC Crop Disease Research Inst., Karachi (Pakistan))

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 8 tables, 42 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: pervezparc@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Thirty soil samples from six important soil series, i.e., Lalian, Miani, Pacca, Rustam, Shahadra and Sultanpur, were collected for determination of micronutrients (Cu, Fe, Mn, Zn) and some physico-chemical properties around Tandojam, Sindh, to establish micronutrients status and to deliberate their adequacy for different crops. The results revealed that soil samples of all soil series were heavy in texture, non-saline and had low organic matter content. All the soil series were low to moderate alkaline in reaction (pH greater than 7.0) and moderately calcareous in nature. Copper contents ranged from 0.22-4.68, Iron 4.45-12.71, Manganese 0.73-4.65 and Zinc had values of 0.07-5.48 mg per kg, respectively. It is concluded that soils around Tandojam were generally adequate in Cu, Fe and Mn, while 40% soil samples were found Zinc deficient. Keeping in view the low content of Zn in soils, Zn fertilization is suggested for better crop production.

ags:resource.dc:title: Effect of integrated nutrient management on nut production of coconut (Cocos nucifera L.) and soil environment - A review

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Baloch, P.A. (SARC/PARC Plant Introduction Centre, Karachi (Pakistan))
Rajpar, I. (Sindh Agriculture Univ., Tandojam (Pakistan). Dept. of Soil Science)
Talpur, U.A. (PARC National Sugar Crops Research Inst., Thatta (Pakistan))

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 5 tables, 65 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: pervezparc@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: With the adoption of new technology of intensive cropping with high yielding varieties, there is a considerable demand on soil for supply of nutrients. However, the native fertility of our soils is poor and cannot sustain high yields. Sustainable agricultural production incorporates the idea that natural resources should be used to generate increased output and incomes, without depleting the natural resources. The solution is application of integrated nutrient management (INM). It is the system, which envisages the use of organic wastes, biofertilizers and inorganic fertilizers in judicious combinations to sustain soil productivity. The conjunctive use of organic and inorganic sources improves soil health and helps in maximizing production as it involves utilization of local sources and, hence, turned to be rational, realistic and economically viable way of supply of nutrients. Coconut is a versatile tree and is the most popular home garden crop in the world. It is very beneficial for health because of its high nutrient status. Integrated nutrient management affects on its growth and yield characteristics to a great extent. This paper, therefore, presents a review on various aspects of INM used to improve soil environment, coconut growth and yield characters.

ags:resource.dc:title: Influence of sowing date on the growth and grain yield performance of wheat varieties under rainfed condition

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Zia-ul-Hassan, M. (Agriculture Extension and Adaptive Research Punjab, Lahore (Pakistan))
Wahla, A.J. (Agriculture Extension and Adaptive Research Punjab, Lahore (Pakistan))
Waqar, M.Q. (Agriculture Extension and Adaptive Research Punjab, Lahore (Pakistan))
Ali, A.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 2 tables, 10 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: ssmsarfchk@hotmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: A field experiment was conducted to evaluate the response of high yielding varieties against varying sowing dates under rainfed conditions during winter 2008-09 at Adaptive Research Farm, Bhaun, Chakwal. Treatments were four sowing dates, viz. D1 (October 15), D2 (October 30), D3 (November 15), D4 (November 30), and five varieties, viz. GA 2002, Chakwal 50, Farid 2006, Wafaq 2001 and Sehar 2006). Sowing dates, varieties and interaction of sowing dates and varieties remained significant on plant height, spike length, spikelets per spike, grains per spike and grain yield (kg per ha). The results showed that wheat variety Chakwal 50 sown on October 30 produced maximum grain yield, followed by Sehar 2006 sown on same date. Yields were reduced by 17.4%, 17.2% and 26.2% from the crop planted on November 15, November 30 and October 15, respectively, as compared with crop planted on October 30. As far as varietal comparison is concerned, yields were reduced by 19.7%, 21.5%, 12.4% and 3.2%, by wheat varieties GA 2002, Farid 2006, Wafaq 2001 and Sehar 2006, respectively, as compared with wheat variety Chakwal 50. Interactive effect of sowing date and wheat varieties also remained significant on grain yield (kg per ha). All planted varieties showed maximum grain yield when planted on October 30. Wheat variety Chakwal 50 sown on October 30 produced maximum grain yield (5684 kg per ha) followed by Sehar 2006 sown on the same date (5183 kg per ha).

ags:resource.dc:title: Synergistic efficacy of organic vegetables under tunnels and field conditions

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Chattha, M.R. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). National Inst. of Organic Agriculture)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 4 tables, 16 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: riaznarc@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: A field experiment was conducted at research fields of National Institute of Organic Agriculture (NIOA), NARC, Islamabad, Pakistan, during kharif 2011-2012. Summer season vegetables, i.e., long gourd, bitter gourd, sponge gourd and French beans, were grown under walk-in tunnels and open field conditions. Vegetable seedlings grown in the first week of July, in polythene tubes, were shifted during the first week of August in open fields. Enriched compost @ 100kg/acre was used in furrows in the plots in two split doses. The results revealed that long gourd, bitter gourd, sponge gourd and French beans yielded 2495.62, 440.78, 596.35 and 1276.97 kg/acre, respectively, as compared to the vegetables in open field condition with the production of 1766.37, 189.59, 147.46 and 1131.13 kg/acre, respectively.

ags:resource.dc:title: Impact of nitrogenous fertilizer on yield and quality of oat

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Iqbal, M.F. (Buffalo Research Inst., Pattoki (Pakistan))
Iqbal, Z. (University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, Lahore (Pakistan))
Farooq, M. (Pest Warning and Quality Control Pesticides, Gujranwala (Pakistan))
Ali, L. (Pest Warning and Quality Control Pesticides, Multan (Pakistan))
Fiaz, M. (Pest Warning and Quality Control Pesticides, Lahore (Pakistan))

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 1 table, 22 ref., Summary (En)
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The present study was conducted at Buffalo Research Institute, Pattoki, during Rabi 2007-08 to evaluate best dose of nitrogenous fertilizer on yield and quality of oat fodder. Highly significant effect on crude protein yield 2.86 t per ha was recorded by the use of nitrogenous fertilizer @ 114 Kg per ha, Digestible crude protein yield was significantly higher 2.10 t per ha and 2.08 t per ha by the use of nitrogen @ 114 kg per ha and 136 kg per ha respectively. However crude fiber (%) was significantly higher 26.96% where nil use of nitrogenous fertilizer but phosphorous and Potash was applied @ 84 and 62 kg per ha respectively. Crude protein (%) produced significantly higher in quality 14.30% with N applied @ 114 kg per ha. Mineral matter contents (%) showed highly significant effect on 12.50%, 12.25% by the use of N @ 136 kg per ha and 114 kg per ha respectively.

ags:resource.dc:title: Mid term evaluation through a tested survey design of project "Aforestation of Blank Areas in State Forest of Murree Hills"

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Mubin, S. (Directorate General of Monitoring and Evaluation, Lahore (Pakistan). Planning and Development Dept.)
Ahmed, M. (Directorate General of Monitoring and Evaluation, Lahore (Pakistan). Planning and Development Dept.)
Ahmed, J. (Directorate General of Monitoring and Evaluation, Lahore (Pakistan). Planning and Development Dept.)
Mubin, G. (Government of the Punjab, Lahore (Pakistan). Punjab Education Foundation)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 2 ills., 2 tables, 13 ref., Summary (En)
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Developing countries in general and Pakistan in particular, face a huge challenge in protecting and sustaining forests. Just in the last five years total area of forest has been reduced from 2.58 percent to 2.19 percent of total area of the country. Numerous programs have been launched at national and international level to conserve the green gold. The project titled Afforestation of Blank Areas in state Forests of Murree Hills District Rawalpindi is the continuity of the steps taken by the Punjab Government to protect and preserve provincial forests. The major objectives of project were afforestation of 5000 acres, protection of natural regeneration of 4000 acres and plantation of 10,000 Platinus Orientalis Varnacular (Chinar) trees in blank areas of Murree hills along with other ancillary work such as soil conservation of 7000 acres. Directorate General Monitoring and Evaluation (DGM&E), P&D department conducted third party evaluation of the project to check whether planned objectives of the project were achieved or not? A comprehensive and systematic statistical methodology for the estimation of proper sample size and testing of hypothesis (i.e. standard No. 27 plants per 50*50 plot have been planted or not) was developed to conduct this evaluation. Evaluation was conducted based on the developed evaluation design and methodology. The results indicated that in Murree Forest Division the overall average number of pits per acre were 471, average survival rate remained 79%, overall deviation from the standard plantation was recorded + 40% and protection of the plants using stones found to be very useful.

ags:resource.dc:title: Role of untreated waste water in spread of antibiotics and antibiotic resistant bacteria in river

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Ahmad, M. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Sustainable Development Study Centre)
Khan, A.U. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Sustainable Development Study Centre)
Wahid, A. (Bahauddin Zakariya Univ., Multan (Pakistan). Dept. of Environmental Science)
Ali, A.S.
Ahmad, F.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 4 ills., 3 tables, 33 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: maqsood_ahmad92@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Water samples were collected from River Ravi upstream and downstream to the city of Lahore to determine role of the city in spread of antibiotic and antibiotic resistant bacteria in the river. All the water samples collected upstream to the city was not contaminated with ciprofloxacin (CIP) and norfloxacin (NOR). Concentration of CIP and NOR in the river downstream to first wastewater drain was 0.032 mug L-1 and the concentration was raised up to 0.125 mug L-1 after the mixing of last drain from the city. Similarly concentration of NOR was raised from 0.026 to 0.093 mug L-1. No antibiotic resistant bacteria were found in the river water upstream to the city. Downstream to the city, the river was contaminated with both Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Vibrio cholerae (V. cholerae).Antibiotic sensitivity tests revealed that both E. coli and V. cholerae were 83.3% resistant to CIP and 66.7% were resistant to NOR respectively. It was concluded that untreated wastewater from the city of Lahore is responsible to contaminate the River Ravi with the antibiotics and antibiotic resistant bacteria.

ags:resource.dc:title: Analysis of planktonic rotifers by shannon-weaver index in Muraliwala (District Gujranwala)

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Sulehria, A.Q.K. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Zoology)
Ejaz, M. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Zoology)
Mushtaq, R. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Zoology)
Saleem, S.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 2 ills., 3 tables, 36 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: khansulehria@hotmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Plankton and physical-chemical analysis is a vital principle for evaluating the quality of a water body. In this study, we attempted to assess the rotifer species richness, diversity, and evenness in four seasons from December 2009 to June 2010 and to predict the state of a natural pond in relation to physical-chemical parameters. A total of 21 rotifer species belonging to 13 genera were recorded. Maximum species of rotifers were present in summer season which were fifteen. The correlation of rotifer population relative to physical-chemical characteristics varied in different seasons. However, rotifers expressed, usually, positive correlation with temperature, and pH whereas negative correlation with other factors. Species diversity and richness was highest in summer and lowest in winter. Analysis of variance showed that there was significant difference in the physical-chemical characteristics of water in different seasons.

ags:resource.dc:title: Nutritional management in brinjal (Solanum melongena L.) using different growing media

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Waseem, K. (Gomal Univ., Dera Ismail Khan (Pakistan). Dept. of Horticulture)
Hussain, A. (Gomal Univ., Dera Ismail Khan (Pakistan). Dept. of Horticulture)

Kiran, M. (Gomal Univ., Dera Ismail Khan (Pakistan). Dept. of Horticulture)
Ghazanfarullah (Gomal Univ., Dera Ismail Khan (Pakistan). Dept. of Agronomy)
Javeria, S. (Gomal Univ., Dera Ismail Khan (Pakistan). Dept. of Food Science and Technology)
Hamid, A.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 2 tables, 17 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: waseemhort@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: A pot experiment was conducted to evaluate the effect of different growing media on the growth and yield of Brinjal, at experimental Horticultural area in Faculty of Agriculture, Gomal University, Dera Ismail Khan, during 2011. The experiment was laid out in CRD with seven treatments, replicated thrice. Different growing media used in the experiment were River soil, Farm yard manure, Poultry manure, River soil + Farm yard manure, River soil + Poultry manure, Farm yard manure + Poultry manure and River soil + Farm yard manure + Poultry manure. Different parameters including number of days taken to flowering, days to fruiting, leaves per plant, plant height (cm), days to harvesting, fruit weight (g), fruit diameter (cm), fruit length (cm), fruit volume (cm3), yield per plant (g) and yield per pot (kg) were studied during the course. For better vegetative growth, it was observed that FYM + Poultry manure performed very well as it took least days to flowering (37.00), days to fruiting (53.50) and days to harvesting (79.93). For reproductive growth, the result showed that a combination of all the media used (River soil + FYM + Poultry manure) showed its supremacy amongst all the other treatments as it produced maximum fruit weight (128.7 g), fruit diameter (10.80 cm), fruit length (14.70 cm), fruit volume (438.1 cm3), yield per plant (386.4 g) and yield per pot (1.159 kg). The least response for all developmental stages, was observed in FYM and Poultry manure respectively, when used alone, in almost all the parameters.

ags:resource.dc:title: Hydraulic fracture job design and developing a smart software for its optimized designing and evaluation reservoir performance

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Zahoor, M.K. (University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Petroleum and Gas Engineering)
Mehmood, F. (University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Petroleum and Gas Engineering)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 1 ill., 12 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: mkzahoor@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Stimulation is a widely applied technique to enhance production of potential reservoirs which cannot deliver because of certain constraints, such as reduced permeability near well bore or low permeability throughout the reservoir. Because of lower permeability and poor productivity a number of wells are shut-in because of their reduced ability to produce; especially while considering economical constraints. So, in such cases, stimulation has its significant role in increasing the well deliverability and productivity and hence bringing such wells to production as well as in general; increasing the production life of the wells. This paper gives a brief insight into usefulness of stimulation job, while specially emphasizing on hydraulic fracturing technique. In addition, an in-house development of software is proposed, which can perform pre and post-frac analysis and also capable of incorporating outputs generated by any commercial reservoir simulator for in-depth and broader analysis and decision making.

ags:resource.dc:title: Best statistical model estimation for mustard yield in Azad Kashmir, Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Saleem, A. (University of Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Muzaffarabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Statistics)
Abbas, K. (University of Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Muzaffarabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Statistics)
Asad, K. (University of Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Muzaffarabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Statistics)
Anjum, M.S. (University of Poonch, Rawalakot (Pakistan). Faculty of Veterinary Sciences)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 6 ills., 4 tables, 10 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: drazharsaleem@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The study proposed a statistical modeling methodology for mustard crop which is the rich source of quality plant proteins and edible oil in Pakistan. We have identified the different mustard plant traits, which contribute to the mustard seed yield significantly, using regression modeling techniques. The necessary assumptions required for regression modeling have been tested and all the assumptions are satisfied by the given data. For the selection of parsimonious model for mustard crop different criterions such as best subset regression and stepwise regression procedures have been applied. Through the modeling process it has been identified that Erucic Acid (X1) and Pods Length (X6) regressors significantly contributes to increase the production of mustard crop in Pakistan.

ags:resource.dc:title: Spatio-periodic monitoring and analysis of atmospheric sulphur dioxide (SO2) in the metropolitan areas of Lahore - Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Mirza, A.I. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Geography)
Shirazi, S.A. (Punjab Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Geography)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 5 ills., 1 table, 13 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: iqtadarmirza@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: For the last three decades, due to population growth and urban development, the mega cities of Pakistan like Karachi and Lahore are experiencing air pollution issues. Out of many, the sulphur dioxide (SO2) in one the most widely researched atmospheric pollutants. Therefore, present research deals with the spatial and periodic distribution of SO2 and its seasonal variations and contamination at fifteen locations in the metropolitan area of Lahore. The sulphur dioxide analyzer's monitoring method has been used to find the concentration and variations which allows instantaneous and continuous analysis of gas in an unaltered state. The industries which are located within or around the metropolitan area of Lahore cause most of the Urban Air Pollution (UAP), especially the emission of sulphur dioxide (SO2).The aims of this study have been to investigate the occurrence of systematic differences in the exposure of SO2 in different Landuse of the Lahore metropolitan areas and to identify the final risk zones of the city. The spatial and temporal perspective of the Lahore combined with the Total Risk Map (TRM) of the metropolitan area highlights the extremely high to extremely low risk zones of the city. The study revealed that Lahore urban area is characterized by a number of hot-spot sites which are mainly due to the industrial emissions. It has been observed that the level of air pollution is severe especially in the Central Business District (CDB) and in and around commercial zones of Lahore. The highest sulphur dioxide values have found near industrial locations, brick kilns and main road crossings areas. Improved technology for negative SO2 emission from industries and steps to control the consumption of low quality coal in brick kilns will lead to reduce the pollution in urban air. The air quality of Lahore can be improved by regular air monitoring and evaluation networks and the integrated approach among the stakeholders both in public as well as private sectors.

ags:resource.dc:title: Potential of indigenous Klebsilla sp. for chlorpyrifos biodegradation

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Farhan, M. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Sustainable Development Study Centre)
Khan, A.U. (Government Coll. Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Sustainable Development Study Centre)
Wahid, A. (Bahauddin Zakariya Univ., Multan (Pakistan). Dept. of Environmental Science)
Ali, A.S.
Ahmad, F.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 5 ills., 23 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: m.farhan_gcu@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Pesticides are one of the major disturbing factors in ecosystems, so their removal/degradation is the need of time. In the present research, 56 microbial strains were isolated from cotton growing areas of Punjab. Strain Ct27 (Klebsiella sp.) was most resistant/effective in chlorpyrifos degradation. Biodegradation potential of Klebsiella sp. was studied under different conditions like; concentration, carbon sources, pH and inoculum densities. Klebsiella sp. showed 90% chlorpyrifos biodegradation (200mgL-1) at pH8 and 10(5) CFU/mL with addition of glucose in 18 days. Presence of other nutrients enhanced chlorpyrifos degradation probably due to high growth on easily metabolizable compounds which in turn favors biodegradation. This strain can be used for bioremediation and ecological restoration of sites, contaminated with chlorpyrifos.

ags:resource.dc:title: Agro-qualitative studies on forage sorghum (Sorghum bicolor L.) sown alone and in mixture with forage legumes

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Akhtar, M.F. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Agronomy)
Azraf-ul-Haq, A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Agronomy)
Ibni Zamir, M.S. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Agronomy)
Khalid, F.
Mohsin, A.U.
Afzal, M.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 3 tables, 27 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: azrafulhaq@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Agro-qualitative response of forage sorghum (Sorghum bicolor L.) sown alone and in mixture with forage legumes was studied through field experiment conducted during the first week of April 2009 at farmer's field at Sahiwal. The experiment was laid out in randomized complete block design (RCBD) comprising of treatments as T1=Sorghum broadcasted, T2=Sorghum at 30 cm apart rows, T3=Broad cast of blended sorghum and cowpea seeds, T4=Blended sorghum and cowpea seeds at 30 cm apart rows, T5=Broad cast of blended sorghum and cluster bean seeds, T6=Blended sorghum and cluster bean seeds at 30 cm apart rows, T7=Broad cast of blended sorghum, cluster bean and cowpea seeds, T8=Blended sorghum, cluster bean and cowpea seeds at 30 cm apart rows, T9=Sorghum sown at 30 cm apart rows and cowpea in between the rows and T10= Sorghum sown at 30 cm apart rows and cluster bean in between the rows. The treatments were replicated thrice with a net plot size was 6m x 4.5 m. All growth, yield and quality parameters were significantly affected by different geometrical arrangement and intercropping systems. Sorghum sown alone in 30 cm apart rows (T2) produced maximum plant population of 47 plants m-2, plant height (203.60 cm), number of leaves per plant (11.23), leaf area (2684.60 cm2), green forage yield (49.66 t per ha) and dry matter yield of sorghum (20.50 t per ha) . Sorghum sown in 30 cm apart rows and intercropped with cluster bean in between the rows (T9) produced significantly higher mixed green forage yield of 69.98 t per ha and dry matter yield of 25.37 t per ha. The maximum crude protein (14.94 %) and ash (10.34 %) was recorded in treatment T8 when blended the seeds of sorghum, cluster bean and cowpea sown in 30 cm apart rows but highest crude fiber (24.15 %) in T1 where sorghum sown alone by broad cast method. Current study revealed that quality and quantity of forage sorghum mixed with forage legumes can be obtained by growing forage sorghum in 30 cm apart rows and cluster bean in between the rows.

ags:resource.dc:title: Comparative yield and yield components of land races and improved soybeans planted on different dates

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Muhammad, A. (University of Science and Technology, Bannu (Pakistan). Dept. of Botany)
Khalil, S.K. (Agricultural Univ., Peshawar (Pakistan). Dept. of Agronomy)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 2 ills., 2 tables, 14 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: asimmuh@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: In order to explore the production potential of land races a comparative study of three land races (Kulat brown, Kulat white and Mothi) and two improved varieties (NARC-II and Swat-84) of soybean at four planting dates (April 2, May 2, June 2 and July 2) in randomized complete block design, replicated four times was conducted at Agricultural University, Peshawar, Khyberpakhtunkhwa, Pakistan during 2004 and 2005. Planting dates significantly affected pods per plant, seeds per pod, 100 seed weight and seed yield. Maximum pods per plant (74.2), seeds per pod (2.1) and seed yield (1459 kg per ha) was recorded for April planted crop. However, May planting produced heaviest seeds (11.5 g 100 seeds-1). Yield and yield components were significantly affected by varieties. Swat-84 gave maximum seeds per pod (2.2) and seed weight (15.7 g 100 seeds-1), while Kulat white produced maximum pods per plant (71.5). Improved variety NARC-II (1366 kg per ha) and land races Mothi (1322 kg per ha) and Kulat white (1281 kg per ha) produced statistically same yield. Heavier seeds were obtained in 2004 as compared to year 2005. For obtaining similar seed yield, land race Mothi should be planted in May and June. Equal seed yield and greater pods per plant of land races, suggested further exploration of land races.

ags:resource.dc:title: Substrate salinity affects growth, yield and quality of Rosa hybrida L.

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Ahmad, I. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Horticultural Sciences)
Khan, M.A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Horticultural Sciences)
Qasim, M. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Horticultural Sciences)
Ahmad, R. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Crop Physiology)
Saleem, M.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 4 ills., 4 tables, 24 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: iftikharahmadhashmi@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The effects of NaCl salinity (control (0.4 dS m-1), 2.5 dSm-1, 5.0 dS m-1, 7.5 dS m-1 and 10.0 dS m-1, respectively) developed after 6 weeks of pruning (beginning of study) on plant growth, flowering and quality of three cut rose (Rosa hybrida L.) cultivars viz. 'Kardinal', 'Anjlique' and 'Gold Medal' was studied to achieve better management, quality production and ascertaining salinity tolerance of cut roses. Number of leaves branch-1, leaf area, leaf total chlorophyll contents, bud diameter, flower diameter and flower quality were greater when plants were grown with canal water (control) having only 0.4 dS m-1 salinity) which also reduced interval between flushes by early flowering, while plant height, number of flowers per plant flush-1, fresh and dry weight of a flower, flower stem length and diameter were higher with 2.5 dSm-1 substrate salinity followed by canal water (control). Among cultivars, 'Anjlique' proved comparatively salt tolerant as compared with 'Kardinal' and 'Gold Medal' by having vigorous growth and higher flowering attributes. In summary, cut roses can not tolerate higher substrate salinity and should be grown with less than 2.5 dS m-1 sodium chloride concentration in the substrate.

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Khanzada, S.R. (Sindh Agriculture Univ., Tandojam (Pakistan). Dept. of Entomology)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 6 ills., 1 table, 24 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: sdrani21.khanzadakhan@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: A field experiment was carried out to determine the relative resistance of soybean cultivars against sucking insect pests in the experimental area of Oilseed Section, Agriculture Research Institute, Tandojam during the Kharif season of 2005. Seeds of ten soybean cultivars (FS-85, AGS-9, AG-109 MA-4085, AGS-8, E-91-=270, PR-142, AGS-20, Wales-2 and Braggs) were sown in rows 45 cm apart in a three replicated Randomized Complete Block Design. It was observed that there was a significant difference in infestation of cultivars by the sucking insect pests. The population of whiteflies and thrip were more abundant during early growth stage, while jassids were more abundant during advanced growth stage of crop. The over all means of pest population showed that thrips were more abundant (3.485 plus minus 0.126) followed by jassid (1.015 plus minus 0.014) and whitefly (0.902 plus minus 0.12) per leaf. The highest thrip (4.107 plus minus 0.369 per leaf) population was observed on cultivar E91-270. The highest jassid (1.253 plus minus 0.275 per leaf) population was observed on cultivar MA-4085. Where as, the highest whitefly (1.093 plus minus 0.15 per leaf) population was found on cultivar FS-85. As far as cultivars are concerned, Wales-2, Braggs and AGS-109 were comparatively susceptible, while PR-142 and AGS-9 were comparatively resistant, however, rest were moderately resistant.

ags:resource.dc:title: Comparative study of pollen traps on improvement in pollen collection technology

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Mahmood, R. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Honeybee Research Inst.)
Asad, S. (PMAS Arid Agriculture Univ., Rawalpindi (Pakistan). Dept. of Economic)
Sarwar, G. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Honeybee Research Inst.)
Iftikhar, F. (National Agricultural Research Centre, Islamabad (Pakistan). Honeybee Research Inst.)
Qadir, Z.A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Entomology)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 4 ills., 26 ref., Summary (En)
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: After designing new pollen trap a trial was laid down in March, 2011 in the premises of HBRI, NARC, Islamabad on sixteen honeybee colonies. All the colonies selected were alike with respect to number of frames and bees present in them. The colonies were divided into four groups. On the first group the Gujranwala (local) pollen trap was clipped while on the second group the newly devised HBRI trap was clipped, on the third group bottom board pollen trap was fitted and on the fourth group Chinese pollen trap was clipped. The pollen drops down through the screens into pollen tray. The weight of pollen collected was compared and it was found that newly design pollen trap (second group) highly significant differ as compared to other three groups (Gujranwala, bottom board, china trap). The total yield of pollen from Gujranwala trap, HBRI, fixed bottom board and the china clipped trap in gm were found to be 83.00 plus minus 3.92 (Mean plus minus SE), 121.50 plus minus 2.87 (Mean plus minus SE), 79.50 plus minus 2.33 (Mean plus minus SE), 66.00 plus minus 1.78 (Mean plus minus SE) respectively. The honey extracted from bee hives with all types of pollen traps was compared and no difference was observed in honey yield.

ags:resource.dc:title: Optimization of germination effect on functional properties of mungbean flour by response surface methodology

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Hussain, I. (University of Poonch Rawalakot (Pakistan). Dept. of Food Science and Technology)
Anjum, M.S. (University of Poonch Rawalakot (Pakistan). Faculty of Veterinary and Animal Sciences)
Uddin, M.B. (Bangladesh Agricultural Univ., Mymensing (Bangladesh). Dept. of Food Technology and Rural Industries)
Ali, S. (Sargodha Medical Coll., Sargodha (Pakistan). Dept. of Biochemistry)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 8 ills., 1 table, 25 ref., Summary (En)
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: The present study focused on functional properties of flours derived from germinated mungbean seeds. Germination process of seed has affect on functional properties like bulk density, absorption capacities, foam capacity, swelling power and solubility. The bulk densities of prepared germinated flours were decreased. Germination decreased water absorption capacities and increased oil absorption capacities in germinated flour sample at ambient conditions for mungbean flour. The foaming capacity of all the prepared samples was increased. Swelling power ranged 7.14 to 7.22%. Solubility increased with increase of germination time. Thus, the study indicated that germination improved the functional properties of flour. Germinated mungbean flour can be successfully used for preparation weaning of foods for proteins deficient children.

ags:resource.dc:title: Marketing margins analysis of seed cotton in district Khanewal, Pakistan

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Manan, A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Business Management Sciences)
Ghafoor, A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan))
Hashmi, A.H. (University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, Lahore (Pakistan). Business Incubation Centre)
Raza, M.A. (Government of the Punjab, Lahore (Pakistan). Planning and Development Dept.)
Shafqat, R. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Business Management Sciences)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 tables, 15 ref., Summary (En)
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: This paper attempts to estimate marketing margins of major intermediaries involved in the marketing of seed cotton in district Khanewal using primary source of data. Formal interviews were conducted from a representative sample of 80 cotton growers, 40 beoparies, 40 commission agents and 40 ginners selected using stratified random sampling technique. The findings of the study indicate that village beoparies (traders) earned gross marketing margin of Rs. 72 per maund (40 Kg), net margin of Rs. 26 per maund and 3.73% margin in marketing chain of seed cotton in district Khanewal. Commission agents earned Rs.35 per maund as gross marketing margin, Rs.23 per maund as net margin and 1.85% margin in marketing chain. The gross marketing margin of ginner was estimated as Rs.136 per maund, net margin as Rs. 45 per maund and 6.56% margin in marketing chain. The study suggests rationalizing the role of middleman to economize and justified margins in the marketing chain of seed cotton in district Khanewal.

ags:resource.dc:title: Effectiveness of upstream blanket and grounting in control of seepage at Khanpur Dam Project

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Farooq, K. (University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Civil Engineering)
Mujtaba, H. (University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Civil Engineering)
Nazir, A. (Water and Power Development Authority, Lahore (Pakistan))
Khan, A.H.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 11 ills., 4 tables, 15 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: kfch95@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Khanpur Dam in Pakistan was constructed on deep alluvial deposits underlain by foundation rock. The dam, since its operation in 1983, has predicament of seepage and in spite of several studies and remedial measures taken in this regard, the problem has not been resolved completely. The present study presents a review of performance of different components of Khanpur Dam in the context of seepage. In this research, Geostudio 2004 package has been used to see the effect of different factors on the quantity of seepage and the results have been validated with the help of field data. The research work concludes that upstream blanket is working efficiently and seepage through the main dam has been stabilized due to the strengthening of the upstream blanket because of sediment deposition. Geostudio analysis as well as field data has indicated that previous grout work at left and right abutments has failed to produce the required results and seepage which is being measured at the downstream toe of the dam is through the abutments instead of through the body or foundations of the dam and recommends that by extending the grout curtain up to a depth of 140' in case of left abutment and to a depth of 160' in case of right abutment, the quantities of seepage can significantly be reduced.

ags:resource.dc:title: Assessment of neighborhood parks using GIS techniques in Sheikhupura city

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Javed, M.A. (Punjab Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Inst. of Geology)
Ahmad, S.R. (Punjab Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Inst. of Geology)
Ahmad, A. (Punjab Univ., Lahore (Pakistan). Inst. of Geology)
Taj, A.A. (Punjab Transport Department, Lahore (Pakistan). Transport Planning Unit)
Khan, A. (University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore (Pakistan). Dept. of Architectural Engineering and Design)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 7 ills., 2 tables, 17 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: m.asifjaved13@gmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Neighborhood Parks have great influence in the sustainability of any city and its accessibility with respect to public is a key factor in measuring the healthy demographic profile. This paper focuses on spatial distribution pattern of 11 existing neighborhood parks within the Sheikhupura city on the basis of road network accessibility. Accessibility has been measured on the basis of standard walk time impedance taken as 60 meters/ minute from residences to the parks. GIS network analysis based on connected road network dataset has been performed to calculate different time zones on the basis of impedance factor. The results showed that existing parks are serving less than 11% out of total population. The comparative statistical analysis also carried out using standard impact buffer distance of 0.5 miles which raised questions upon spatial distribution pattern as well as number of parks in the city. GIS techniques and methods provided helpful tools in analyzing accessibility of existing park facilities. The output can be used by decision making authorities to formulate plans for suitable park locations in the city.

ags:resource.dc:title: Can catalase and exopolysaccharides producing rhizobia ameliorate drought stress in wheat?

dc:creator.ags:creatorPersonal: Hussain, M.B. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Soil and Environmental Sciences)
Zahir, Z.A. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Soil and Environmental Sciences)
Asghar, H.N. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Inst. of Soil and Environmental Sciences)
Asgher, M. (University of Agriculture, Faisalabad (Pakistan). Dept. of Chemistry and Biochemistry)

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 6 ills., 5 tables, 48 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: zazahir@yahoo.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Catalase and exopolysaccharides producing ability of rhizobia increases its survival in arid and semiarid climates. Rhizobial exopolysaccharides activity increases root colonization and nutrient or water holding capacity of the rhizosphere. For the reason, a series of experiments were conducted to sort out efficient rhizobial isolates (belonging to Lens culinaris L., Vigna radiata L. and Cicer arietinum L. cultivated in Chakwal (arid) and Faisalabad (semiarid) areas which can ameliorate the impact of water deficit stress on wheat seedlings. Among 35 isolates, Rhizobium leguminosarum (LR-30), Mesorhizobium ciceri (CR-30 and CR-39), and Rhizobium phaseoli (MR-2) improved the growth, biomass and drought tolerance index of the wheat seedlings under PEG-6000 simulated drought. Selected isolates were producers of indole acetic acid, which enhanced the root length of the seedlings to dilute the drought impact. However, isolates LR-26, MR-17 and CR-34 remained deleterious for seedling growth whether drought was applied or not. In conclusion, rhizobial capability to survive under drought and improving seedling growth under drought is a good criterion to select beneficial bacteria for rescuing wheat seedlings growth under water deficit conditions.

dc:description.ags:descriptionNotes: 3 ills., 1 table, 36 ref., Summary (En), E-mail: yy.peng@hotmail.com
dc:description.dcterms:abstract: Phenotypic diversity based on morphological traits was estimated in 114 accessions from 25 Avena species. Analyses showed that there was abundant genetic diversity in all species. In the quantitative characters, shattering habit had the highest phenotypic coefficient of variation (140.42%), and wheel layers had the lowest one (17.31%). In qualitative characters, color of glumelle had the highest genetic diversity index (H=1.3), while grain color had the lowest one (H=0.41). Correlation analysis of quantitative characters showed that the plant height (PH) and grain number per panicle (GNP) were the main factors which can increase yield. Principal component analysis (PCA) showed that 89.3% of the total variation of quantitative characters could be explained by the first five components. Comprehensive evaluation of agronomic characters revealed that several accessions, including accessions CN 25766 and CN 25787 (A. hispanica), PI 545459 (A. fatua), CN 21703 (A. hirtula), Ciav 8330 (A. maroccana), PI 636073 and CN 64226 (A. sativa) were to be promising parents in high grain yield and lodging resistance breeding. Based on agronomic characters, diploid species A. lustanica and A. wiestii were different from other diploid As genome species. A. Murphyi was closest to hexaploids in the three AACC tetraploid.
